elements.Text: Networking connects devices (e.g., computers, printers) for communication, resource sharing, and data exchange.
It supports systems from simple home networks to global infrastructures.
Examples: Home devices connected to Wi-Fi, corporate LANs, and public services like online government portals.
Personal Devices: Use Wi-Fi or Bluetooth for file sharing and streaming.
Corporate Systems: LANs for secure collaboration and shared resources.
Public Services: Governments rely on networks for databases and online services.
Enables ATM connectivity, inter-branch operations, and customer support.
Ensures 24/7 service reliability through robust networks.
Real-time fund transfers, secure online payments, and fraud detection through encrypted systems.
Support instant processing with high availability, used in applications like instant messaging and stock trading.
Printers: Shared printers reduce costs and improve efficiency.
File Servers: Centralized storage enhances collaboration and reduces redundancy.
Cost Savings: Shared hardware, software licenses, and energy efficiency optimize expenses.
Admins can monitor traffic, deploy updates, and enforce security from a central location.
Telegraph: Enabled coded message transmission (Morse Code).
Telephone: Allowed real-time voice communication over long distances.
Morse Code & Switching Stations: Streamlined long-distance communication.
Telegraph Lines & Submarine Cables: Connected cities and continents.
Improved efficiency and reliability, forming the foundation of modern internet systems.
Definition: Connects devices within a limited area like a home, office, or school.
Switches: Manage data flow within the LAN, reducing congestion.
Routers: Connect LANs to external networks like the internet.
Devices: Include computers, printers, and storage tools.
Shared Drives: Centralized file storage enabling secure access and collaboration.
Benefits: Real-time updates, version control, and enhanced team productivity.
Definition: Connects multiple LANs across large geographic areas.
Internet as a WAN: Connects billions of devices globally, enabling e-commerce, communication, and social media.
Multinational Operations: Centralized management and unified communication (e.g., video conferencing).
Data Sharing: Real-time synchronization, fast file transfers, and cloud integration for global collaboration.
Definition: The layout of devices (nodes) and connections (links) in a network.
Physical Topology: Actual arrangement of hardware (cables, devices).
Logical Topology: Defines data flow irrespective of physical setup.
Impact: Affects network speed, redundancy, and troubleshooting efficiency.
All devices connect to a central hub (e.g., switch).
Centralized control simplifies management and troubleshooting.
Failure of individual devices doesn’t disrupt the network.
Centralized Devices: Hub or switch ensures efficient data routing.
Scalability: New devices can be added seamlessly with minimal disruption.
